thread.title: Brexit vote six months on: Who are the winners and who are losers?
thread.title_full: Brexit vote six months on: Who are the winners and who are losers?

author: Sean Seddon
title: Brexit vote six months on: Who are the winners and who are losers?
text:
How the EU referendum night unfolded Share this video Watch Next 
That’s a big margin of victory and a majority of people, presuming they still feel the same way, should be feeling rather pleased. 
Following successive Conservative victories despite strong Labour showings in the North East, the region has backed the losing horse in every major election since 2005. 
For the first time in a while most of our voters were on the winning side. LOSERS: Tourists Since the UK voted to leave the European Union in June, the UK's currency has been fluctuating in value against other currencies, including the Euro and the dollar (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Brexit has already made the cost of going on holiday more expensive. 
A volatile currency market has gone up and down but the general trend has been downward. 
Take travelling to Europe, for example. Read More North East now wants to stay in the European Union according to our Brexit poll 
In practice, this means that if you changed £500 to Euros at the start of the year you’d have got €680 in return. 
If you had changed the same amount of money when the pound hit a low, you’d have got a measly €555 back. 
The pound has recovered slightly recently but as negotiations drag on over 2017 the pound will probably slump even further. 
Going on holiday could get very pricey next summer. WINNER: UKIP A person wearing a Ukip rosette (Photo: Daniel Leal-Olivas/PA Wire) 
It’s been a strange few months for UKIP. 
They’ve had two leadership races, a scandal involving a confrontation between two MEPs and Nigel Farage has alienated many over his friendship with the president elect of the United States. 
For any other party at any other time this would look like a terrible state of affairs. 
And yet, the future looks rosy for the populist insurgents. 
In his victory speech, UKIP’s new leader, Paul Nuttall, said he wanted to “replace” the Labour party. 
That’s unlikely but there’s no doubt he’s in a good position to loosen Labour’s grip on places like the North East. 
As Labour grandee Frank Field put it to The Guardian, Nigel Farage “picked up a million Labour voters by accident”. 
Arguably for the first time in their history, and without Europe dominating their field of vision, UKIP have a target - and a wounded one at that. 
The Labour party is hobbling and across the country voters are turning away. 
UKIP have a very real chance of turning that into success on councils and perhaps in constituencies across the North East. 
Which brings us to... LOSER: The Labour Party Jeremy Corbyn, the Labour leader, speaking at the Labour Party Annual Conference 2016 (Photo: Daily Mirror) 
The North East belongs to an increasingly rare species: the Labour stronghold. 
There’s not a single Tory MP between Stockton and Hexham. 
But in a post-Brexit world things look less straight forward. 
Labour, who are hitting historic lows in national polls, have yet to formulate a coherent Brexit policy and have been hampered by turmoil in the party since the result. 
Broadly speaking, Labour favour some sort of soft-Brexit, although they are vague on the details. 
Jeremy Corbyn and the rest of the party leadership have remained relatively coy on what they would like to see post 2019 and have at times been outshouted by those in the party who want to see a second referendum. 
The result is that they’re simultaneously pleasing no one and angering everyone. 
Labour voters who backed Remain, particularly in London, want to see the party commit to offering a second vote and are looking to the vocally pro-Europe Liberal Democrats. 
But Labour voters who opted for Leave in places like the North East are turning to UKIP and the Tories to make sure what they voted for is actually delivered. 
The type of wipe-out the party experienced in Scotland remains a remote possibility but the North East will certainly be more competitive now, especially if Theresa May calls a snap general election. 
Following the resignation of Corbyn-critic Jamie Reed in Copeland, Cumbria, there’ll be a crucial by-election in the coming months. 
Demographically similar to parts of the North East, Copeland could act a pretty good indicator of how Labour will perform in the coming years in the North East. 
Labour have held the seat since 1983 - William Hill have the Tories 5/4 favourites to win it. Read More
